metadata.name: Suspicious Recursive Takeown
metadata.comment: Adversaries can interact with the DACLs using built-in Windows commands takeown which can grant adversaries higher permissions on specific files and folders

batch.sql: SELECT * FROM process_activity WHERE time BETWEEN CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() - INTERVAL 24 HOUR AND CURRENT_TIMESTAMP() AND (activity_id = 1 AND endswith(lower(process.name), lower('\\\\takeown.exe')) AND contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('/f ')) AND contains(lower(process.cmd_line), lower('/r')))

output.summary: Adversaries can interact with the DACLs using built-in Windows commands takeown which can grant adversaries higher permissions on specific files and folders

metadata.objective: Examine fields: process.cmd_line, process.parent_process.cmd_line False positives: 1. Scripts created by developers and admins 2. Administrative activity References: https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/administration/windows-commands/takeown, https://github.com/redcanaryco/atomic-red-team/blob/f339e7da7d05f6057fdfcdd3742bfcf365fee2a9/atomics/T1222.001/T1222.001.md#atomic-test-1---take-ownership-using-takeown-utility
